anchor.surface_text: On the 3rd of December, 1960, the Karnataka Government promulgated the Mysore Public Works Engineering Department Services  Recruitment  Rules, 1960  hereinafter referred to as the Recruitment Rules  under Article 309 of the Constitution of India, which envisaged appointment of Assistant Engineers in the Public Works Department by direct recruitment to the extent of 40 per cent and by promotion for the rest, viz., 50 per cent from the cadre of Junior Engineers and 10 per cent from the cadre of Supervisors.

concepts.interpretation: Quota rule 40% direct, 60% promotion; not applicable to pre-1.3.1958 promotions or first filling; amended retrospectively from 1.3.1958.

It was argued that the regularisation of the promotion gave it the companyour of permanence and the appointments of the promotees as Assistant Engineers must therefore be deemed to have been made substantively right from the 1st of November, 1956.

concepts.interpretation: Regularisation cures procedural defects but does not confer permanence or substantive status; cannot override Art 309 rules.
concepts.unlisted_description: Does not mean conferring permanence on irregular appointments

anchor.surface_text: Officers appointed substantively in clear vacancies shall be senior to all persons appointed on officiating or any other basis in the same cadre of service or class of post

issues.text: Whether the scope of the writ petitions instituted by the promotees was limited to the question of promotion of Assistant Engineers to Executive Engineers such that no challenge to the seniority list dated 4th September 1973 could be entertained

anchor.surface_text: The first contention we would like to deal with is one raised by Mr. F. S. Nariman appearing for the direct recruits. He argued that the scope of the writ petitions instituted by the promotees was limited to the question of promotion of Assistant Engineers as Executive Engineers and that no challenge to the seniority list dated the 4th of September, 1973 could be entertained. In this connection reference was made to the prayer clause appearing in Writ Petition No. 462 of 1973 which is in the following terms

issues.text: Whether the promotees had been regularly promoted as Assistant Engineers against substantive vacancies with retrospective effect

anchor.surface_text: During the year 1973 more writ petitions challenging the promotion of direct recruits to the posts of Executive Engineers were instituted by the promotees on whose behalf two claims were made before the High Court, namely  1  that they had been regularly promoted as Assistant Engineers against substantive vacancies with retrospective effect and rightly so and  2  that in the case of those of them whose promotion was made effective from a date prior to the 1st of March, 1958, the Recruitment Rules, especially the quota rule, could not affect them adversely.

issues.text: Whether in the case of promotees whose promotion was made effective prior to 1st March 1958, the Recruitment Rules especially the quota rule could affect them adversely

anchor.surface_text: that they had been regularly promoted as Assistant Engineers against substantive vacancies with retrospective effect and rightly so and  2  that in the case of those of them whose promotion was made effective from a date prior to the 1st of March, 1958, the Recruitment Rules, especially the quota rule, could not affect them adversely. Both these claims were accepted by the High Court, the first on the basis of the decision of this Court in Ram Prakash Khanna others v. S. A. F. Abbas 1  coupled with the pleadings of the parties and the various orders issued by the State Government and mentioned above,

issues.text: What is the real dispute between direct recruits and promotees regarding the quality of tenure held by promotees immediately prior to enforcement of Recruitment Rules in light of rule 2 of Seniority Rules

anchor.surface_text: The real dispute between the direct recruits and the promotees revolves round the quality of the tenure held by the latter immediately prior to the enforcement of the Recruitment Rules and that is so because of the language employed in rule 2 of the Seniority Rules. The relevant portion of that rule is extracted below Subject to the provisions hereinafter contained, the seniority of a person in a particular cadre of service or class of post shall be determined as follows Officers appointed substantively in clear vacancies shall be senior to all persons appointed on officiating or any other basis in the same cadre of service or class of post

issues.text: Whether the promotion of the 107 officers from Merged State of Mysore was to substantive posts of Assistant Engineers with effect from 1st November 1956

anchor.surface_text: in the light of the said clauses  a  and  b  therefore that learned counsel for the State and the direct recruits have challenged the finding of the High Court that the promotion of the 107 officers working in the Merged State of Mysore was made to substantive posts of Assistant Engineers with effect form the 1st of November, 1956 and that the State Government or the direct recruits could not be allowed to urge to the contrary. The controversy has to be resolved in the light of the orders passed by the State Government from time to time in relation to those officers and others similarly situated.

issues.text: Whether regularisation of promotees appointments confers permanence or substantive status retrospectively from 1st November 1956
Whether regularisation is permissible in exercise of executive powers under Article 162 in contravention of rules framed under Article 309

Appointments of direct recruits valid despite after Recruitment Rules, as process initiated earlier under Article 162

N. Nagarajan v. State of Mysore others  wherein it was held that their appointments, although made after the Recruitment Rules had come into force, were valid, as the process of direct recruitment had been set in motion by the State Government in exercise of its executive powers under article 162 of the Constitution of India well before the Recruitment Rules were promulgated

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tion, they would all rank junior to the direct recruits who, from the very start, held appointments made substantively in clear vacancies. We may here

arguments.claim: Promotees appointments as AE prior to Recruitment Rules were not illegal or outside government powers

anchor.surface_text: Nor can it be urged with any plausibility on behalf of direct recruits that the appointment of the promotees as Assistant Engineers prior to the enforcement of the Recruitment Rules lay outside the powers of the Government or was otherwise illegal.

holdings.text: The scope of the writ petitions instituted by the promotees was not limited to the question of promotion of Assistant Engineers to Executive Engineers; challenge to the seniority list dated 4th September 1973 could be entertained.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that no prayer has been made by the promotees to quash or rectify the seniority list dated the 4th of September, 1973, but then their whole case is based on the contention that they had been promoted to the posts of Assistant Engineers in a substantive capacity prior to the appointment of the direct recruits, that they would take precedence over direct recruits in the matter of seniority and regular absorption in the cadre of Assistant Engineers and that it was on that account that the promotion of direct recruits to the posts of Executive Engineers without consideration of the case of the promotees for such promotion was illegal. The attack on the said seniority list therefore is inherent in the case set up by the promotees, of which it forms an integral part. In this view of the matter we cannot agree with Mr. Nariman that the scope of the writ petitions is limited as stated by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Attack on seniority list inherent in promotees' case claiming substantive prior promotion and precedence over direct recruits.

holdings.text: Appointment of direct recruits to Assistant Engineers valid despite made after Recruitment Rules came into force, as process initiated earlier under Article 162.

anchor.surface_text: No exception is or can be taken on behalf of the promotees to the finding arrived at by the High Court that the appointment of direct recruits to the posts of Assistant Engineers was in order, in view of the judgment of this Court in B. N. Nagarajan v. State of Mysore supra . Nor can it be urged with any plausibility on behalf of direct recruits that the appointment of the promotees as Assistant Engineers prior to the enforcement of the Recruitment Rules lay outside the powers of the Government or was otherwise illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedent in B.N. Nagarajan; executive power under Art 162 initiated recruitment before rules.

holdings.text: Appointment of promotees as Assistant Engineers prior to enforcement of Recruitment Rules not outside government powers or illegal.

anchor.surface_text: Nor can it be urged with any plausibility on behalf of direct recruits that the appointment of the promotees as Assistant Engineers prior to the enforcement of the Recruitment Rules lay outside the powers of the Government or was otherwise illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Government had power to appoint before rules framed under Art 309.

holdings.text: Direct recruits appointed substantively in clear vacancies per rule 2(a) Seniority Rules and Probation Rules definitions.

anchor.surface_text: In view of these definitions it cannot be gainsaid that the direct recruits were appointed Assistant Engineers substantively in clear vacancies as envisaged by clause (a) of rule 2 of the Seniority Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Probationary direct recruits are substantive appointments in clear vacancies per Probation Rules rule 2.

holdings.text: Promotees held appointments as Assistant Engineers in non-substantive capacity (officiating or temporary) throughout relevant period.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Government orders specify officiating/temporary; no substantive appointment evidenced.

holdings.text: Promotion of 107 officers from Merged State of Mysore not to substantive posts with effect from 1st November 1956.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Initial and subsequent orders indicate officiating/temporary tenure, not substantive.

holdings.text: Regularisation does not connote permanence or confer substantive status; cures only procedural irregularities.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedents State of Mysore v. Narayanappa and Nanjundappa; regularisation not mode of recruitment or permanence.

holdings.text: No regularisation permissible under executive power Art 162 in contravention of rules under Art 309.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules under Art 309 prevail; executive cannot override by regularisation post-rules.

holdings.text: Promotees rank junior to direct recruits under Seniority Rules.

anchor.surface_text: This being the position, they would all rank junior to the direct recruits who, from the very start, held appointments made substantively in clear vacancies.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substantive direct recruits senior to non-substantive promotees per rule 2(a) Seniority Rules.

holdings.text: Order does not cover pre-1.11.1956 substantive holders or those acquiring substantive status pre-Recruitment Rules and pre-direct recruits.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Carves out exceptions for prior substantive appointments outside dispute.

holdings.text: Quota rule not applicable to first filling of cadre under Recruitment Rules proviso.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to rule 2 allows first direct recruitment without percentages.

holdings.text: Seniority determined per Seniority Rules; Recruitment Rules implemented from 1.3.1958.

anchor.surface_text: It goes without saying that all questions of seniority shall be decided in accordance with the Seniority Rules and that the Recruitment Rules, as amended from time to time, shall be fully implemented as from the date of their enforcement, i.e., 1st of March, 1958.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directs application of rules post-determination of substantive status.

In this view of the matter we cannot agree with Mr. Nariman that the scope of the writ petitions is limited as stated by him.
